column4: Disney World actors ready to work after COVID testing dispute resolved
column5: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - Walt Disney World actors, who argued that the Florida theme park’s proposed coronavirus safeguards were inadequate to protect them, have resolved a dispute over COVID-19 testing, a union statement said on Wednesday.
column6: The Actors’ Equity Association had called on Walt Disney Co to provide regular coronavirus testing for its members, who cannot wear protective masks while performing as other park employees do.
column7: Disney said on Wednesday it would provide space just outside Walt Disney World in Orlando for a testing site run by the Florida Division of Emergency Management. The site will be open to Disney employees, known as cast members, and the public.
column8: “Our actions support all cast and our community at large,” Disney said in a statement.
column9: Walt Disney World reopened on July 11 with several safety measures including limited attendance, social distancing in lines and on rides and mask requirements for guests and staff.
column10: Actors’ Equity, which represents roughly 750 stage performers at the park in shows such as the Indiana Jones Stunt Spectacular and Beauty and the Beast Live on Stage, said the measures did not go far enough and called for regular testing. Disney opened the park without the performers.
column11: “We have been consistent that testing is an important part of ensuring a safe workplace for Equity performers, and today, I’m pleased to see that Disney World has agreed,” Actors’ Equity Association President Kate Shindle said.
column12: The union said it had signed a memo of understanding with Disney and was waiting to hear how many workers the company would recall during its limited operations. In June, before the testing dispute, Disney had called back about 220 actors and singers, the union said.
column13: Disney said it offered testing space “to help with community testing” and that “any suggestion that this has been done as a result of any one union is unfounded.”

column4: Walt Disney World actors to return to work after company offers COVID-19 tests
column5: LOS ANGELES, Aug 12 (Reuters) - Actors who had objected to Walt Disney Co’s proposed coronavirus safeguards at the Walt Disney World theme park have reached an agreement to return to work, according to a union statement on Wednesday.
column6: Actors’ Equity Association said Disney had committed to providing COVID-19 tests at the Florida theme park for its members, who cannot wear protective masks while performing. (Reporting by Lisa Richwine Editing by Chris Reese)

column4: Indonesia imposes 10% VAT on Facebook, Disney, Tiktok
column5: JAKARTA (Reuters) - Indonesia has added more technology companies that will be obligated to apply 10% value-added tax on sales to Indonesian customers to include Facebook, Disney and TikTok, its tax office said on Friday.
column6: Southeast Asia’s biggest country, which has a population of nearly 270 million people, announced last month a 10% VAT on sales by technology firms including Amazon, Netflix, Spotify and Google, as spending patterns shift with increased remote working amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has hit government finances.
column7: The additional companies announced on Friday include three units of Facebook, Tiktok Pte Ltd, Apple Distribution International Ltd, The Walt Disney Company (Southeast Asia) Pte Ltd, and more of Amazon’s subsidiaries, including its audiobook unit Audible and its voice assistant Alexa.
column8: Facebook said the company would comply.
column9: “In Indonesia, we will start collecting VAT as of September 1, 2020, as required under Indonesia regulations,” a Facebook spokeswoman said.
column10: The other companies did not immediately respond to requests to comment.
column11: Under the rules, non-resident foreign firms which sell digital products and services in Indonesia worth at least 600 million rupiah ($41,040) a year, or which generate yearly traffic from at least 12,000 users, must pay the 10% VAT.
column12: Tech giants are increasingly facing tougher fiscal regimes in Southeast Asia, including in Thailand and the Philippines, where legislation pending house approval proposes VAT of 7% and 12% respectively.
column13: The Indonesian tax office in a statement said it continues to identify other technology companies to inform them of the digital tax rules, adding the number of firms subject to the VAT would likely increase.
column14: The VAT rules aim to create a level playing field between foreign and local companies and between conventional and digital businesses, it said.
column15: Indonesia expects a 13% annual drop in state revenue this year as the coronavirus disrupts business activity.

column4: Wonderful world of Disney earnings surprise boosts Wall Street
column5: NEW YORK (Reuters) - U.S. stocks climbed on Wednesday on the heels of a surprise quarterly profit from Disney and as investors stayed optimistic that a deal was near for a U.S. coronavirus fiscal aid package.
column6: Walt Disney Co's DIS.N shares jumped 8.80%, to put it among the biggest boosts to the S&P 500 and Dow. The stock notched its biggest daily percentage gain since March 24 as revenue declines for Disney parks and media networks were not as bad as feared.
column7: “That is helping the Dow and that has been a laggard versus the S&P this year, but it is more than that,” said Willie Delwiche, investment strategist at Baird in Milwaukee. “At a time when everyone is talking about how big and how important these megacaps are to the S&P, kind of quietly you are starting to see a little bit of a leadership rotation.”
column8: The Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI rose 373.05 points, or 1.39%, to 27,201.52, the S&P 500 .SPX gained 21.26 points, or 0.64%, to 3,327.77 and the Nasdaq Composite .IXIC added 57.23 points, or 0.52%, to 10,998.40.
column9: Square Inc SQ.N surged 7.10% after the payments processor reported a 64% rise in second-quarter revenue, as consumers increased online buying and used its peer-to-peer Cash App platform during the pandemic.
column10: As quarterly results have come in better-than-feared and heavyweight technology and technology-related companies have surged, a heavy dose of fiscal and monetary stimulus have helped fuel a rally in equities to bring the S&P 500 to less than 2% from its closing record on Feb. 19.
column11: With 384 companies in the S&P having reported earnings through Wednesday morning, results are coming in 23.5% above expectations, in aggregate, according to Refinitiv data, the highest on record back to 1994.
column12: Economic data painted a mixed picture, as U.S. services industry activity gained momentum in July, according to an ISM survey, with new orders jumping to a record high. However, hiring declined, supporting views that a recovery in the labor market was faltering.
column13: Earlier, the ADP National Employment Report, which can be an inconsistent precursor to the government payrolls report set for Friday, showed U.S. private employers hired far fewer workers than expected last month.
column14: “We know we had this tremendous rebound off the lows but what we need now is sustained strength,” said Delwiche.
column15: Friday is being viewed as a deadline by one of the lead negotiators for the White House and some Senate Republicans in talks with congressional Democrats on a fresh round of coronavirus aid, or talks will be scrapped.
column16: Financials .SPSY, industrials .SPLRCI and materials .SPLRCM, that track economic growth, outperformed among the major S&P sectors.
column17: Teladoc Health Inc TDOC.N fell 19.01% after agreeing to buy chronic care provider Livongo Health Inc LVGO.O in a deal valuing the company at $18.5 billion, betting on a boom in online care and consultations spurred by the coronavirus crisis. Livongo shares fell 11.40%.
column18: Electric truck maker Nikola Corp NKLA.O slumped 9.81% after it reported a bigger quarterly loss in its first results as a listed entity.
column19: Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the NYSE by a 2.47-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 2.14-to-1 ratio favored advancers.
column20: The S&P 500 posted 50 new 52-week highs and no new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 208 new highs and 10 new lows.
column21: About 10.09 billion shares changed hands in U.S. exchanges, compared with the 10.43 billion daily average over the last 20 sessions.

column4: US STOCKS-Disney's wonderful world helps lift Wall St
column5: (For a live blog on the U.S. stock market, click or type LIVE/ in a news window)
column6: * U.S. services sector activity hits 16-month high in July
column7: * Biggest daily pct gain for Disney since late March
column8: * Energy stocks gain as oil prices jump
column9: * Dow up 1.2%, S&P 500 up 0.66%, Nasdaq up 0.55% (New throughout, updates prices, market activity and comments; new byline, adds NEW YORK dateline)
column10: NEW YORK, Aug 5 (Reuters) - U.S. stocks climbed on Wednesday in the wake of a surprise quarterly profit from Disney and as investors hailed signs that a deal was near for a U.S. coronavirus fiscal aid package.
column11: Walt Disney Co’s shares jumped 9.06%, among the biggest boosts to the S&P 500 and Dow, and was on track for its biggest daily percentage gain since March 24 as revenue declines for its parks and media networks were not as bad as feared.
column12: “What is helping not just Disney but the markets in general is everyone is completely buying into the Disney move to streaming but then if you do look at the theme parks, the data for the U.S. at large has gotten much more positive lately where we are at least getting initial indications we are sort of over that hump,” said Shawn Cruz, senior manager of trader strategy at TD Ameritrade in Jersey City, New Jersey.
column13: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 321.61 points, or 1.2%, to 27,150.08, the S&P 500 gained 21.96 points, or 0.66%, to 3,328.47 and the Nasdaq Composite added 59.92 points, or 0.55%, to 11,001.09.
column14: Payments processor Square Inc surged 8.50% after reporting a 64% rise in second-quarter revenue, as consumers increased online buying and used its peer-to-peer Cash App platform during the pandemic.
column15: As quarterly results have come in better-than-feared and heavyweight technology and technology-related companies have surged, a heavy dose of fiscal and monetary stimulus have helped fuel a rally in equities to bring the S&P 500 less than 2% from its closing record on Feb. 19.
column16: With 384 companies in the S&P having reported earnings through Wednesday morning, results are coming in 23.5% above expectations, in aggregate, according to Refinitiv data, the highest on record back to 1994.
column17: Economic data painted a mixed picture, as U.S. services industry activity gained momentum in July, according to an ISM survey, with new orders jumping to a record high. However, hiring declined, supporting views that a recovery in the labor market was faltering.
column18: Earlier, the ADP National Employment Report, which can be an inconsistent precursor to the government payrolls report set for Friday, showed U.S. private employers hired far fewer workers than expected last month.
column19: U.S. Congressional Democrats and White House officials were set to resume negotiations on coronavirus relief legislation on Wednesday, with administration officials aiming for an agreement by Friday.
column20: Financials, industrials and materials , that track economic growth, outperformed among the major S&P sectors.
column21: Teladoc Health Inc fell 17.30% after agreeing to buy chronic care provider Livongo Health Inc in a deal valuing the company at $18.5 billion, betting on a boom in online care and consultations spurred by the coronavirus crisis. Livongo shares fell 10.23%.
column22: Electric truckmaker Nikola Corp slumped 8.16% after it reported a bigger quarterly loss in its first results as a listed entity.
column23: Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the NYSE by a 2.27-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.93-to-1 ratio favored advancers.
column24: The S&P 500 posted 48 new 52-week highs and no new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 202 new highs and 9 new lows. (Reporting by Chuck Mikolajczak; Editing by David Gregorio)

column4: Disney takes $5 billion hit but pandemic impact not as bad as feared
column5: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - Walt Disney Co DIS.N on Tuesday avoided the unmitigated disaster some investors feared as it eked out an adjusted profit amid the coronavirus pandemic that shut down parks, movie theaters and sporting events across the globe.
column6: Disney’s quarterly profit of 8 cents per share on an adjusted basis beat expectations for a loss of 64 cents, sending the stock up 5% in after-market trade.
column7: The company took a nearly $5 billion charge due to the pandemic and shifting media habits. COVID-19 wiped out $3.5 billion in operating profit in the parks division.
column8: “The majority of businesses worldwide have experienced unprecedented disruption as a result of the pandemic,” Disney Chief Executive Bob Chapek told analysts. “Most of our businesses were shut down, and this had a huge impact.”
column9: Investors overlooked total revenue that fell short of expectations by nearly $600 million and focused on divisions including parks and its media networks with revenue declines that were not as bad as expected.
column10: The Disney+ streaming service, which had 60.5 million paying customers as of Monday, was a bright spot in the quarter, Chapek said. Disney had reported 54.5 million subscribers as of May 4.
column11: “What we plan to do is invest even more in our content in order to keep that machine cranked and going,” he said.
column12: Combined with Hulu and ESPN+, Disney has attracted more than 100 million streaming customers worldwide since launching its big streaming effort nine months ago. Netflix Inc NFLX.O, which got a head start in the market when it began streaming 13 years ago, boasts 193 million.
column13: The coronavirus outbreak forced Disney to delay the theatrical debut of movies including the live-action epic “Mulan” about a Chinese warrior.
column14: In a surprise move, Disney said it will release “Mulan” on Disney+ on Sept. 4 for people to watch at home at a cost of $30, and in theaters in markets where Disney+ is not available.
column15: Chapek said the shift was a one-time event and did not represent a shift in strategy.
column16: The decision followed a deal in July between Comcast Corp's CMCSA.O Universal Pictures and cinema chain AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc AMC.N to allow the studio to release films directly to consumers after just three weeks in theaters, down from the average three months.
column17: Disney also said it would launch a new international streaming service under the Star brand.
column18: “Investors are looking beyond the tough quarter to continued reopening of parks, while Disney+ is expected to see further growth,” said Investing.com analyst Haris Anwar.
column19: Theme park closures from April to June led to an operating loss of $1.96 billion in the parks and consumer products business. Even as four of its six theme park resorts around the world have opened, social distancing rules have limited attendance.
column20: Demand at profit center Walt Disney World was lower than expected because of the resurgence of coronavirus infections in Florida, Disney Chief Financial Officer Christine McCarthy said.
column21: The media network segment, which includes ESPN and Disney channels, reported a 48% jump in operating income to $3.15 billion.
column22: The direct-to-consumer and international unit, which houses the Disney+ streaming service, reported an operating loss of $706 million, below the $1.06 billion that analysts expected.
column23: Operating income at the movie studio fell 16% to $668 million as many movie theaters remained closed.
column24: Overall revenue fell 42% to $11.78 billion. Analysts on average had expected revenue of $12.37 billion, according to Refinitiv IBES data.
column25: Net loss from continuing operations was $4.72 billion, or $2.61 per share, in the third quarter ended June 27, compared with a net profit of $1.43 billion, or 79 cents per share, a year earlier.
